title: Bells and Chain-Song
description: Low tide draws its slow breath and the Glass Parliament’s floor-script awakens in gleam and silt, each clause surfacing like a fish’s silver spine before sinking again. Abbatess Serene Khel calls Raithe Calder to the Hall of Winter Ledgers, where stone sweats cold and memory-ink shivers in its well like a patient sea. She would cross ring three to the Basilica of the Drowned Star with novices in tow, bearing a sealed recollection to be verified where tide-water kisses the altar and the drowned names are sung. Rumors spiral through the alleys that some hidden cog remembers starfire and hums when the choirs climb into their high notes, and that the Tide-Gate’s chain-song has begun to answer like a choir of brass. As bells measure the city’s pulse, Raithe’s bone-chime earring replies to a bell no hand rings, and his rib-scar—which maps the city like old pain—aches as if a compass suddenly found north. Eel oil and salt ink musk the air; a Mnemos novice cradles a memory case like a relic saved from a burning library. Outside the Basilica, Iria Venn in Lantern Cartel blue waits with a pilot’s impatience and a warning braided from fog, false light, and convoys hovering at the Salt Spires. All threads tug the same knot: the city breathes through gates and song, but who owns the lungs, and whose hand will hold the next breath a little too long.
objectives: Escort Serene Khel and her novices from the Hall of Winter Ledgers to the Basilica of the Drowned Star during the ebb, keeping them safe as law and tide walk together.
Stand watch during a sanctioned recollection while the tide-water rises at the altar, defending the rite until the memory is witnessed and sealed again by holy song.

Observe and report any resonance between the Basilica’s hymn and the Tide-Gate Crown’s chain-bells, taking special note of hums, tremors, or answering tones that suggest a hidden cog remembers starlight.
Meet Iria Venn outside the Basilica and exchange safe fog codes, ensuring pilots can steer by true signals instead of the false bells that lead ships onto teeth.

dialogue.speaker: Serene Khel
dialogue.lines: Raithe Calder, three days of your youth sleep in our ink, and I keep the key not as a gaoler but as a gardener who tends a wintered seed. Today I do not ask you for more of your past; I ask for your presence, for the steadiness of a shoulder that has learned when to fight and when to listen. Walk with me as memory crosses stone to meet the sea, for there is a place where law becomes song and song dissolves into law, and tonight the seam between them feels thin. There is a hum beneath the obvious hymn, a resonance that troubles my quiet, and I would hear it with a witness who knows the city’s breath from the inside. Guard my novices, guard the case we carry, and guard your own heart, because when names drowned for safety are sung aloud, the city remembers not just what it wants but what it fears.

dialogue.speaker: Raithe Calder
dialogue.lines: Mother Abbatess, I’ve caught broken bottles on a buckler and taken a chain across the chest to hold a crowd from crushing its own, and yet it’s the singing stones that make my knees remember old falls. If the city has a second voice beneath the choirs, I’ll hear it, and if the voice belongs to some hidden hand, my falchion will ask it to show itself. I don’t forget what the gates can do when a lever is pulled too late or too soon, nor what it costs to bury a memory so deep it takes ink to breathe it back. I’ll carry you across ring three even if the Wharfers and Saltwardens decide to play tug-of-war with us in the middle. And if the chain-bells answer the hymn, I’ll mark the tone on my tongue and carry it back to your ledgers the way a pilot carries a light through fog.

dialogue.speaker: Iria Venn
dialogue.lines: You still brace like you expect the world to hit you, Raithe, and sometimes it does, but today it’s the fog that wants the bruise. The beacons have started getting answers they didn’t send, little echoes cupped in the hollows between tolls, and the convoy off the Salt Spires grows skittish as eels at the sheen of a blade. If the Basilica’s hymn calls something in the Tide-Gate Crown and that something rings our codes back at us, I have to decide whether to nose them home or hold them where the black teeth of the reef wait. Tell me the truth when you feel it, not the comfort, because I’d rather bite down on a bitter bell than sweeten my chart with a lie. And when we trade fog codes, I want the ones you’d trust with your own breath, not the ones you’d hand a stranger to keep your hands clean.

dialogue.speaker: Alion Mareth
dialogue.lines: You arrive in good time for a dangerous harmony, Raithe Calder, and in this house we call that providence with an edge. The Drowned Star was bound to our city with a promise sung by throats that have long turned to salt, and promises like that do not lie quiet forever. The chain-bells of the Crown were meant to measure tide and labor, not to answer to a relic, and yet the city’s metal has learned the choir’s steps and would dance if unobserved. Stand with the Abbatess and let your watch be a kind of litany, for a faithful guard is a verse in a larger hymn. If you hear a note that does not belong to sea or saint, bring it to me in words, because we must decide whether to bless it as part of the covenant or bind it as a trespasser at our altar.

choices.title: Walk the open causeway with banners veiled
choices.text: Lead Serene Khel and the novices along the main ring-three causeway under the eyes of guild banners and the eel-oil lamps of the Saltwardens, keeping your formation obvious and your intentions lawful. The procession moves with deliberate slowness, letting the city see that memory does not skulk, and you hold your buckler high to turn curiosity into respect. Wharfers pause their handcarts and Ratchet Syndicate mechanics watch from crane-shadows, measuring your stride against rumor, as if truth itself wore boots. The chain-song from the Crown rides the wind in steady links, and at each bell you taste copper like the edge of a storm, a flavor you will not forget when asked to testify. You know the risk of being seen is also the price of being believed, and you judge the risk worth paying because law and hymn ask for witnesses, not whispers.
choices.outcome: The open route draws a knot of onlookers that nearly turns to a bottleneck, but your crowd-craft keeps the flow from collapsing, and a few rough tongues turn polite when you name the Abbatess with the dignity she is due. A Saltwarden sergeant tries to fold the procession under his authority, but you parry with tidelaw etiquette, invoking the sanctioned recollection writ, and he settles for escorting your flank, grumbling but compliant. As the Basilica rises, a low overtone threads through the chain-bells and brushes the choir’s warm-up like a cold finger, and you watch Serene Khel’s eyes flick in the same instant, confirmation that you did not imagine it. Inside the rite, the resonance returns in the second verse and vibrates your bone-chime earring as if a far bell nodded, and you mark the pitch against the memory of the gates. Iria meets you after and takes the true fog code you offer without flinching, trusting your open-road choice, and she warns that Matriarch Luma Keel will want a word soon about lights that answer to prayers they were never taught.

choices.title: Thread the shadowed rib-alleys and omens
choices.text: Guide the Mnemos party through the narrow ribs beneath the Leviathan Bone Bridge and along markets where omens are read in striped shadows, choosing silence over ceremony and steadiness over spectacle. You move like a kite on a calm, barely tugging the line, and the novices learn your pace, placing their feet where your hooks would bite. In the hush of those alleys the chain-song grows more intimate, like breath passing between two cupped hands, and the city’s inhale and exhale feel personal. You nod to shrine-keepers and they nod back, recognizing a vow in your finger-knotted ring and letting you pass with the deference given to a man escorting a dangerous promise. You keep your hand on the memory case when the crowd swells and your other hand on your buckler when the quiet grows too perfect, because either can smother a rite.
choices.outcome: The shadowed route avoids confrontation and gives you a clean approach to the Basilica’s side door, where Alion Mareth greets Serene with a look that says he, too, heard something in the quiet. During the recollection, the first verse passes like a breath held, but in the second refrain your ear catches a thin, glassy whistle braided under the hymn, and your windglass visor reveals faint ripples in the air that tug toward the river mouth. You report this to Serene and Alion with the calm of a man who knows the difference between superstition and sign, and they exchange a glance heavy with old maps and older oaths. Because you came by the ribs, shrine-keepers later share a small omen: the bone hummed after the choir’s last note, a hum that aligns with the gate’s third chain-bell. Iria arrives in the alley instead of the square, grateful for your caution; she trades you a deeper set of fog codes and asks for a promise that if the bells sing back, you will call her first before any guild tries to own the sound.

choices.title: Leverage Lantern light to veil the crossing
choices.text: Ask Iria Venn to throw a soft curtain of Cartel beacons along your path, a drifting lattice of honest light designed to make false bells hesitate and opportunists squint. The city becomes a theater where ships might be, and your procession plays a quiet part on a lit stage none but pilots know how to read. You step where the light nods you forward and pause where it thickens, and the novices learn to trust brightness the way sailors trust a steady hand on the tiller. Your bone-chime earring settles as if soothed by the honest code, and even the chain-song seems to soften its iron a fraction when the Cartel’s rhythm hums true. You accept the debt you incur with the Lantern Cartel but measure it against the safety you buy, and in your ledger of the heart the mark feels worth it—if you can pay it clean later.
choices.outcome: The veiled route keeps hecklers and pickpockets at an elegant distance, and where a snag of bodies might have formed, the beacons deepen like a harbor and let your party slip through. At the Basilica, the hymn rises and the chain-bells answer once, twice, and then hush as Iria’s code shifts, and you feel plainly that the gates can be coaxed by song and light as much as by lever and gear. Serene Khel takes note of the interplay with a scholar’s hunger and a penitent’s caution, and Alion Mareth murmurs that this knowledge is a bridle better kept coiled than flaunted. After the rite, Matriarch Luma Keel’s runner delivers a polite chit reminding you that borrowed light expects a return, and Iria squeezes your hand like an apology and a dare at once. The fog codes you trade are the safest she has, and she adds a spoken warning: if a bell no hand rings begins to set schedules, the Cartel will demand a seat at the altar or turn every beacon into a question the guilds cannot answer.

rewards.description: Sanctioned Mnemos recall token (one use), a palm-warm wafer of unburnable parchment that entitles the bearer to fix a single witnessed detail for lawful recall.
25 silver marks in clipped ring-mint coin, paid from the Order’s quiet purse for discreet protection rendered at ebb.
Order of Mnemos favor: Priority scriptorium access for one hearing at the Hall of Winter Ledgers, placing your testimony or petition at the front of the recall docket.
Safe audience with Tidebound Conclave chantmasters at the Basilica of the Drowned Star, granting you entry to consult on rites when hymn and law entwine.
